metadata.title: Multiple-Input Deep Convolutional Neural Network Model for COVID-19 Forecasting in China 2

affiliation.institution: Jiangxi University of Science and Technology
National Pingtung University of Science and Technology
Jiangxi University of Science and Technology

abstract.text: COVID-19 is spreading all across the globe. Up until March 23, 2020, the confirmed cases in 173 12 countries and regions of the globe had surpassed 346,000, and more than 14,700 deaths had resulted. The 13 confirmed cases outside of China had also reached over 81,000, with over 3,200 deaths. In this study, a 14 Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) was proposed to analyze and predict the number of confirmed cases. 15 Several cities with the most confirmed cases in China were the focus of this study, and a COVID-19 16 forecasting model, based on the CNN deep neural network method, was proposed. To compare the overall 17 efficacies of different algorithms, the indicators of mean absolute error and root mean square error were 18 applied in the experiment of this study. The experiment results indicated that compared with other deep 19 learning methods, the CNN model proposed in this study has the greatest prediction efficacy. The feasibility 20 and practicality of the model in predicting the cumulative number of COVID-19 confirmed cases were also 21 verified in this study.

body_text.text: CoV-2), and it has, at the time of writing, spread in over 173 countries, causing more than 15,000 deaths. The 31 epidemic is still spreading, and the WHO has classified the global risk level of the disease as a "pandemic." 32 Currently, the earliest known case symptoms appeared on December 1, 2019, and the first case sought treatment 33 on December 8. On December 26, 2019, Wuhan City Respiratory and Intensive care doctor Zhang Jixian first 34 discovered this pneumonia with unknown cause and suspected that it is an infectious disease. Subsequently, the 35 disease broke out in Wuhan City. On January 20, 2020, Chinese academic Zhong Nanshan publicly announced 36 that the novel coronavirus pneumonia "definitely transmits between people." On January 23, 2020, the Wuhan 37 City Government announced the adoption of lockdown and quarantine measures in the infected areas, which 38 was the first case of lockdown in a major city (with a population of 11 million) in recent public health history.

Since January 13, the disease continued to spread to Thailand, Japan, and South Korea. On January 30, three 40 countries outside China were verified as having interpersonal propagation, and the pandemic was thus 41 designated as an international public health emergency event by the WHO.

According to reports on the epidemic, "the propagation speed is faster, and the virus propagation power 43 has increased." Infected people can infect others with the virus while exhibiting no symptoms; and the latency 44 from infection to the presentation of symptoms is as long as 14 days. These characteristics also increase the 45 difficulty of controlling the epidemic. As the epidemic continues, there is also a problem of the global 46 undersupply of surgical masks. Currently, no vaccine and remedy for the novel coronavirus have been 47 discovered. WHO assistant director-general Bruce Aylward stated that Remdesivir is currently the only drug 48 . The China-Japan Friendship Hospital in China and the 49 American National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases are starting to conduct clinical trials for the drug.

At present, no sufficient knowledge regarding the disease is known, and key factors, such as virus source, virus 51 birthplace, morbid mechanism, virus pathogenicity, and propagation power are still uncertain. The structure of this study proceeds as follows. The first section introduces the entire study. The second 135 section is a literature review. The following third section details this study's proposed deep neural network 136 algorithm. The fourth section presents and discusses the experiment results in detail. Finally, the fifth section 137 concludes the entire study and underscores the contribution of this study and the predicted trend of the COVID-138 19 epidemic.

FIGREF0.text: December 2019, the first case of COVID-19 infection was discovered in Wuhan City in China's 26 Hubei Province [1]. In the following weeks, this disease broke out within China and continued to spread 27 extensively in other countries, causing worldwide panic. The pneumonia caused by this novel coronavirus was 28 officially named the Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) by the World Health Organization (WHO). The 29 2019 coronavirus epidemic was triggered by the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-

FIGREF1.text: 73 Moreover, the Galton-Watson branch was used to analogize virus propagation, thus determining the 74 connectivity and transmissibility between China and the destination country. The disadvantage of this method 75 is that the uncertainty regarding the efficacy of control measures against the disease results in difficulties in 76 predicting the development trajectories of the disease. By comparison, Al-Qaness et al. [6] adopted the adaptive 77 neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS), an improvement from flower pollination algorithm and salp swarm 78 algorithm, to predict the number of confirmed cases in the next 10 days. The comparison with the ANFIS 79 optimized with GA, PSO, ABC, and FPA indicated that the accuracy of the FPASSA-ANFIS model reached 80 0.97, and the predicted average increase in numbers of new cases in the next 10 days was 10% more than the 81 number of present cases. Jung et al. [7] used the rate of increase together with delayed distribution estimation 82 and statistical induction to establish a mathematical model, based on COVID-2019 case data reported before 83 January 24. The predicted cumulative number of confirmed cases for up until January 24 was 6,924, and the 84 predicted death ratio was 5.3%; these figures were within the 95% confidence interval. Compared with previous 85 methods for establishing mathematical models, Fan et al. [8] adopted a statistical method for predicting the 86 floating population in Wuhan City. The experiment indicated that the floating population in Wuhan region is 87 highly correlated with the number of daily confirmed cases. The residence time of the floating population for 88 local cases was longer than that for non-local cases, which results in a lower predicted number of confirmed 89 cases in the areas around Hubei Province. The prediction results indicate that approximately 80% of the 90 epidemic will be centralized in the top 30 districts. 91 However, applications of deep learning methods have mainly used the genome of the 2019-cCoV virus to 92 predict disease propagation. Yang et al. [9] used the Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Removed model to 93 integrate the epidemic curve, combining it with the long short-term memory model. The maximum value was 94 reached on February 28, and the curve gradually lowered in late April. Hu et al. [10] used an improved stacked 95 autoencoder and a cluster algorithm to group the instantaneous confirmed cases in every province; they noted 96 a high accuracy in AI-based methods for COVID-19 trajectory prediction. The epidemic was predicted to end 97 in mid-April. Guo et al. [11] used deep learning-based virus host prediction to compare the gene sequence of 98 2019-nCoVs with those of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (SARS-CoV), bat SARS corona 99 virus, and Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus (MERS-CoV). The bat SARS coronavirus 100 was discovered to have a more similar mode of infection to COVID-19. Metsky et al. [12] used a nucleic acid 101 .

FIGREF2.text: nCoV has the potential for continual infection between people.Liu et al. [14]  compared 2019-nCoV with 107 SARS and estimated the doubling time of 2019-nCoV and SARS as well as the basic reproduction number r0 108 and time-varying instantaneous reproduction number rt through data analysis. They discovered that the 109 infectivity of 2019-nCoV may be stronger than SARS, but that disease control efforts are effective.Ming et al.   110    [15] adopted an improved version of the Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered (SIR) model to predict the actual 111 number of infection cases of 2019-nCoV as well as the actual load on the intensive care units under different 112 diagnosis rates and public health intervention efficacies. They discovered that under a 50% diagnosis rate and 113 no public health intervention, the actual number of cases will be significantly higher than the reported number, 114 whereas under a 70% public health intervention, the load on the health system will decrease substantially. Zhao115 et al. [16] used a probability prediction model to accurately predict the infection nodes from snapshots of 116 spreading. Fountain-Jones et al. [17] used machine learning to establish pathogen-risk models and compared 117 the prediction results of different machine learning methods and explained the results by using game theory. 118 Benvenuto et al. [18] adopted an autoregressive integrated moving average model to predict the epidemic 119 trend and morbidity of 2019-nCoV with a 95% confidence interval. They discovered that if the virus does not 120 mutate, the case number will reach a plateau. Li et al. [19] used a function to separately describe the daily 121 infection and death data of 2019-nCoV in Hubei and outside Hubei. The author thought that the inflection point 122 in the Hubei region was at February 6, 2020, and that the epidemic will end on March 10, 2020, with an 123 estimated infection rate of 39,000 people. However, the data did not include the data after February 12, where 124 such inclusion will increase the predicted figures by 1.4 times. Yang et al. [9] described the clinical 125 characteristics and imaging manifestation of the infected cases of COVID-19 that had been confirmed in the 126 hospitals in Wenzhou area. In addition, the patients with and without travel or residence history in Hubei were 127 compared. Tian et al. [20] analyzed the clinical and epidemiological characteristics of COVID-19 in the Beijing 128 area. The characteristics of severe confirmed cases and common confirmed cases were compared, and the 129 characteristics of COVID-19 and SARS were compared as well. Chen et al. [21] analyzed some cases of 130 pregnant women with COVID-19 and noted no evidence that COVID-19 causes intrauterine infection through 131 vertical transmission among women in late pregnancy. The major contribution of that study is its fast 132 establishment of a prediction model by using deep learning with a small dataset, making it an important 133 reference for other countries in their containment of the COVID-19 epidemic.

FIGREF4.text: Neural Network (ANN) [22, 23] is a mathematical model that mimics how neurons operate 144 in organisms. It is a very powerful tool for establishing nonlinear models. An early ANN structure is the 145 Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), which uses the neural network of fully connected structures; it has decent efficacy 146 and numerous applications. However, if the data is too complex, simply using the MLP structure may cause the 147 model to be unable to effectively learn how to handle every situation. At present, ANN has already developed 148 into various new structures. The main structure of this study is the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) [24, 149 25], and three other neural network structures are compared with it. These four neural network structures are 150 detailed in the following subsections.

FIGREF5.text: convolution operation[26]  is illustrated inFig. 2. The difference between CNN and MLP is that 153 CNN uses the concept of weight sharing. As illustrated inFig. 2, the advantage of CNN is that its weight number 154 does not have to be as large as that for a fully connected structure. Consequently, the training is relatively easier, 155 and important characteristics are extracted more effectively. CNN is a feedforward neural network, which is an 156 improvement from MLP. CNN contains four levels in structure: an input layer, convolutional layer, pooling 157 layer, and fully connected layer.158The deep CNN structure proposed in this study is illustrated inFig. 2, and the structure is composed of 159 CNN and the dropout layer. The input layer structure is constituted by six time sequences composed of factors 160 influencing the cumulative number of cases. The convolutional layer structure is divided into four layers, and 161 each convolution layer has 16, 32, 32, and 64 convolutional kernels. Going through every convolutional layer, 162 the convolutional kernels of the previous layer slide in the input data matrixes. The convolution process can be 163 expressed in Equation (1), in which is the ith and jth matrix in the row and column direction, respectively, 164 corresponding to the convolution kernels in the input matrix through smooth shifting. K is the

FIGREF10.text: Gate recurrent unit 222 The Gate Recurrent Unit (GRU) [29, 30] is a variation of the LSTM, as illustrated in Fig. 5 (a). GRU 223 changes the input gate and forget gate of LSTM into the update gate. GRU retains the effect of LSTM and 224 simplifies the internal structure of GRU model units. The principle of GRU's update gate is described in 225 Equation (10). Specifically, the neural unit information of the previous moment ℎ −1 and the input data of

FIGREF19.text: MAE radar charts. (a) Six factors were adopted as the input layer. (b) Only one factor was adopted as the radar charts of MAE values for the comparison between the output results 329 and real values for six and one factors, respectively. Regardless of whether one or six factors were used, the 330 prediction results, in terms of MAE, of the proposed CNN model were superior to those of its counterparts. For 331 the proposed CNN model, the use of six factors yielded better prediction results, in terms of MAE, in 332 comparison to the use of only one factor, particularly for Wuhan CityRMSE radar charts. (b) Only one piece of 335 information was adopted as the input layer.336 Fig. 14 (a) and (b) presents the radar charts of RMSE values for the comparison between the output results 337 and real values for six and one factors, respectively. The results further demonstrated the excellent predictive 338 performance of the proposed CNN model for the cumulative number of confirmed cases of COVID-19, making 339 the model a valuable reference for other countries in their establishment of country-specific COVID-19 340 prediction models. In general, the prediction performances of the models from most favorable to least favorable 341 were those for CNN, GRU, LSTM, and MLP.

TABREF0.text: people have been infected with the virus; among these people, 14,765 54 have died. The several European countries with the most severe epidemics have experienced the maximum 55 increase in confirmed cases in a single day on March 5: cases for Italy increased from 3,089 to 3,858, those for Germany increased from 262 to 482, those for France increased from 285 to 423, and those for the Netherlands 57 increased more than twofold from 38 to 82. In the WHO report on February 26, the numbers of new cases in China and Japan have decreased, but the numbers of new cases in Italy, Iran, and South Korea are still rising.At the time of writing, the numbers of confirmed cases in Germany, France, and Spain have surpassed 1,000.Fig. 1 [2] presents the global map of COVID-19 occurrence according to data from the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The countries marked with a color are countries with confirmed 63 cases. At present, 173 of the 195 countries in the world have confirmed cases, underscoring the epidemic's 64 astounding speed of propagation from its origin in China's Hubei province. Most scholars have used 65 mathematical models to predict the spread of COVID-19. Roosa et al. [3] used the generalized logistic model, 66 the Richards model, and the sub-epidemic model to establish prediction models for the cumulative numbers of 67 confirmed cases in Guangdong Province and Zhejiang Province. They predicted that, in the next 5 days and 10 68 days from their time of writing, 65-81 and 44-354 new cases will appear in Guangdong and Zhejiang provinces, 69 respectively. In addition, Liu et al. [4] used mathematical models to simulate the propagation status of COVID-70 19 in China and noted the importance of the government's policy of limiting public activities and the movement 71 of infected people with no symptoms. Boldog et al. [5] adopted a Time-Dependent Compartmental Model of 72 the Transmission Dynamics to estimate the cumulative number of confirmed cases outside of Hubei Province.

TABREF9.text: EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS IN TERMS OF ROOT MEAN SQUARE ERROR OF THE INPUT LAYER OF A SINGLERegarding the deep neural network prediction results for six and one-input factors, the MAE and RMSE318 values are listed in Tables 1 to 4. The MAE results from low to high are as follows: CNN (102.943, 284.573), GRU (2599.150, 1916.904), LSTM (2992.976, 3324.591), and MLP (5710.293, 5811.429). The RMSE results 320 from low to high are as follows: CNN (109.439, 325.857), GRU (2602.666, 1924.361), LSTM (2994.851, 321 3331.925), and MLP (5715.125, 5816.079). The experiment results demonstrated that GRU and LSTM have 322 decent efficacies and that CNN had the best performance. This experiment also demonstrated that the procedure 323 of initial characteristic extraction through CNN and the subsequent input of characteristic values to the CNN 324 structure greatly aid the prediction of the cumulative number of confirmed cases of COVID-19.

TABREF10.text: Conclusions343A novel and multi-input CNN deep neural network model was proposed in this study to predict the 344 cumulative number of confirmed cases of COVID-19. The cumulative number of confirmed cases in the next 345 day is predicted according to the previous five days' total number of confirmed cases, total confirmed new cases, 346 total cured cases, total cured new cases, total deaths, and total new deaths. In the experiment, the datasets of 347 those seven Chinese cities with severe confirmed cases-from Hubei Province, Guangdong Province, and Zhejiang Province-were used for the models' training and prediction. Because the COVID-19 epidemic is 349 ongoing, the algorithm proposed in this study can rapidly use small datasets to establish models with high350 predictive accuracy, different from many other studies. In addition, with the algorithm, a deep learning network 351 prediction model for the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 was established, and the verification and 352 comparison were conducted among different deep learning algorithms. The accuracy and reliability of the deep 353 learning algorithm were verified by having it predict the future trend of COVID-19. Furthermore, experiments 354 for multiple cities with more severe confirmed cases in China indicated that the prediction model of this study 355had the lowest error rate among its counterparts tested. However, at the time of writing, countries other than China have had COVID-19 outbreaks, such as Italy, South Korea, Iran, Spain, France, and Germany. In the 357 future, the establishment of more complete databases will lead to improvements to the proposed prediction 358 model. For example, deep learning networks with a mixed structure can be introduced to establish more accurate 359 models, which can be applied to more countries. The predicted trends can aid the containment of the COVID-360 19 epidemic and extend the scope of application of artificial intelligence.
